issues.title: Oil Leaks (Chain Tensioner and Case Seams)
issues.symptoms: Oil spots under car, oil on engine, seepage visible, low oil level, burning smell
issues.description: Like its predecessor, the 993 is prone to oil leaks. The most common source is the chain tensioner cover, but leaks also develop at case seams, valve covers, cam tower seals, and oil cooler connections. The 993 added hydraulic valve lifters which also have potential leak points at the lifter galleries.
fixes: Chain tensioner cover reseal (common and accessible)
Valve cover gaskets replacement
Cam tower seal replacement (more involved)
Case seam resealing (requires engine removal)
Oil cooler line inspection and replacement
Use correct Porsche sealant specifications

repairCosts.notes: Chain housings and cam covers most common. Valve cover O-rings.

issues.title: Dual-Mass Flywheel Wear
issues.symptoms: Clutch chatter, vibration at idle, rattling noise, harsh engagement, gear engagement difficulty
issues.description: The 993 continues with the dual-mass flywheel to dampen drivetrain vibrations. These flywheels have a service life and their internal springs and dampers wear out. A worn DMF causes chatter, vibration, and can damage the clutch disc and transmission input shaft bearing. Replacement is recommended with any clutch service.
fixes: Replace dual-mass flywheel (OEM or quality aftermarket)
Single-mass flywheel conversion (increases NVH but more durable)
Replace clutch disc, pressure plate, and release bearing
Inspect input shaft bearing while transmission is out
Resurface or replace DMF if within spec

repairCosts.notes: Same as 964. DMF failure common on high-mileage cars.

issues.title: Hydraulic Lifter Noise and Failure
issues.symptoms: Ticking noise on cold start, persistent ticking, reduced power, misfire, rough idle
issues.description: The 993 was the first 911 to use hydraulic valve lifters, eliminating the need for periodic valve adjustments. However, these lifters can develop issues - they may tick on cold start (often normal) or persistently (indicating wear). Using improper oil or extended oil change intervals accelerates lifter wear.
fixes: Use proper viscosity oil (Porsche specification)
Regular oil changes to maintain lifter hydraulics
Lifter replacement for persistent ticking (labor intensive)
Some ticking on cold start is normal - observe if it clears
Check oil pressure if lifter noise is widespread

repairCosts.notes: Lifter tick on cold start. Replace in sets.

issues.title: G50/52 Transmission Issues
issues.symptoms: Grinding into gear, synchro failure, gear pop-out, shift cable wear, notchy shifting
issues.description: The 993 uses the G50 six-speed transmission. While robust, synchros wear over time, particularly second gear. The shift cables also wear and need adjustment or replacement. Improper fluid or aggressive cold shifting accelerates synchro wear. Some 993s have the limited-slip differential which has its own service needs.
fixes: Regular transmission fluid changes with GL-4 spec fluid
Shift cable adjustment or replacement
Synchro replacement requires transmission rebuild
Allow transmission to warm up before aggressive shifting
LSD service if equipped (inspect during trans work)

repairCosts.notes: Same G50 as 964. Synchro wear common.

issues.title: Suspension Component Wear
issues.symptoms: Clunking over bumps, vague handling, uneven tire wear, loose steering feel, wandering
issues.description: The 993 introduced a completely redesigned multi-link rear suspension replacing the semi-trailing arms of earlier 911s. All suspension bushings, ball joints, and tie rods wear over time. The rear suspension has numerous bushings that affect alignment and handling. Worn components significantly diminish the 993's excellent handling.
fixes: Comprehensive suspension inspection and refresh
Replace all worn bushings (OEM rubber or polyurethane)
Rear suspension overhaul (multiple bushings per side)
Front control arm bushings and ball joints
Replace tie rods and steering components as needed
Full alignment after suspension work

repairCosts.notes: 30-year-old bushings need replacement. LSA upgrade available.

issues.title: Power Steering System Failures
issues.symptoms: Whining pump, heavy steering, fluid leaks, intermittent assist, groaning noise
issues.description: The 993 hydraulic power steering system shares components with the 964. The pump, rack, hoses, and reservoir all age. Power steering pump bearings fail causing whining. Rack seals leak. Hoses deteriorate internally and externally. Regular fluid changes help longevity.
fixes: Power steering fluid flush (use Pentosin CHF 11S)
Pump rebuild or replacement
High-pressure line replacement
Rack seal replacement or rack rebuild
Reservoir cleaning and line inspection

repairCosts.notes: Hydraulic system ages. Check pump and rack.

issues.title: Climate Control and HVAC Issues
issues.symptoms: AC not cooling, heater not heating, blend door clicking, fan not working, temperature fluctuation
issues.description: The 993 climate control system is complex and prone to age-related failures. The blend door actuators (servos) fail, causing clicking noises and incorrect temperature output. The AC compressor, condenser, and evaporator develop issues. The heater core can leak. Blower motor resistors fail.
fixes: Blend door actuator (servo) replacement
AC system diagnosis and repair
R-134a conversion if still on R-12
Heater core replacement (labor intensive)
Blower motor or resistor replacement
Full climate control diagnostic before major work

repairCosts.notes: Blower motor and resistor common. AC conversion available.

issues.title: Turbo-Specific Issues (993 Turbo)
issues.symptoms: Boost problems, wastegate issues, intercooler leaks, turbo failure, check engine light
issues.description: The 993 Turbo uses twin KKK turbochargers. While generally reliable, the turbo system has specific maintenance needs. Wastegates can stick, boost hoses crack, and intercoolers can develop leaks. Oil feed and drain lines must be inspected. Turbo bearing wear occurs at high mileage.
fixes: Wastegate inspection and service
Boost hose inspection and replacement
Intercooler leak testing
Turbo oil line inspection and replacement
Turbo rebuild or replacement at high mileage
Proper warm-up and cool-down procedures

repairCosts.notes: 993 Turbo only. Wastegate actuators and boost issues.

guides.title: Complete Suspension Refresh
guides.description: Full front and rear suspension rebuild for the 993, the last air-cooled 911 and the first with multi-link rear suspension. This guide addresses worn bushings, shocks, and steering components to restore the legendary handling.
guides.interval: Every 60,000-80,000 miles or when handling degrades
tools: Floor jack and jack stands rated for vehicle weight
Pickle fork or ball joint separator
Large pry bar for control arm manipulation
steps: Raise vehicle and support securely on jack stands under reinforced jacking points.
Remove all four wheels and set aside in safe location.
Document current ride height and alignment settings before disassembly.
Begin with front suspension - disconnect sway bar end links (18mm).
Remove tie rod ends from steering knuckle using pickle fork.
Support the strut assembly before disconnecting from knuckle.
Remove strut pinch bolt and disconnect from knuckle.
From above, remove the three 13mm nuts holding strut top mount.
Remove strut assembly and replace with new unit or rebuild.
Remove front control arms - mark bolt positions for camber reference.
Press out old bushings and press in new ones, or replace complete arms.
For the rear multi-link suspension, start by disconnecting shocks.
Remove upper control arms (two bolts each) - note any shim washers.
Remove lower control arms - larger bolts requiring more torque.
Remove toe links from hub carrier - affects rear toe setting.
Replace trailing arm bushings - requires press for removal and installation.
Install new rear components - apply threadlocker to specified bolts.
Replace rear shock absorbers - access through wheel well.
Reassemble in reverse order, torquing all fasteners to spec.
Rear multi-link upper bolts: 63 ft-lbs (85 Nm).
Rear multi-link lower bolts: 74 ft-lbs (100 Nm).
Front control arm bolts: 63 ft-lbs (85 Nm) - tighten with weight on wheels.
Install wheels and torque lug bolts to 96 ft-lbs (130 Nm).
Professional alignment is critical after multi-link rear work.
tips: The 993's multi-link rear suspension was a major upgrade over the 964's semi-trailing arms.
Elephant Racing offers complete suspension kits with polyurethane options.
The multi-link design allows precise camber, toe, and anti-squat adjustment.
OEM rubber bushings provide good street manners; poly is more responsive.
Bilstein Sport or Koni adjustables are popular upgrades from stock shocks.
Consider lowering springs (H&R, Eibach) if replacing for track use.
Check CV boots and axles while suspension is disassembled.
The 993 is the most refined air-cooled 911 - proper suspension is key to the experience.
warnings: The 993's rear multi-link has many adjustment points - document everything.
The car weighs approximately 3,100 lbs - use appropriate jack stands.
Rear suspension work significantly affects alignment - budget for professional alignment.
Some fasteners use threadlocker from factory - apply new threadlocker on reassembly.
Cars with LSA (load-sensitive damping) have special shocks - verify before ordering.
Always tighten suspension fasteners with weight on wheels for proper bushing loading.

guides.title: Rust Prevention and Repair
guides.description: Comprehensive guide to inspecting, preventing, and repairing rust on the 993. Covers common problem areas including rocker panels, floor pans, battery box, and rear spring plate areas critical to this collectible last air-cooled 911.
guides.laborHours: Varies significantly by extent of rust
tools: Wire brush and wire wheel attachments
Angle grinder with cutting and grinding discs
DA sander with various grit discs
Spray gun for primer and underseal
Safety equipment: welding helmet, gloves, respirator
steps: Thoroughly clean undercarriage with pressure washer to expose rust areas.
Raise vehicle and inspect all common rust locations systematically.
Check rocker panels by pressing firmly - soft spots indicate internal rust.
Inspect battery box area in front trunk - acid damage is common here.
Examine floor pans from inside with carpet removed and from below.
Check kidney areas where front fenders meet body - debris traps moisture.
Inspect jack point reinforcements - critical structural areas.
Examine spring plate covers in rear - these rust from road spray.
Check around rear suspension mounting points for corrosion.
For surface rust: sand to bare metal, treat with rust converter, prime and seal.
For perforation rust: cut out affected area 1 inch beyond visible rust.
Treat surrounding metal with rust converter before patching.
Fabricate or purchase repair panels to fit openings.
Apply weld-through primer to mating surfaces.
Tack weld panels in place, checking fit frequently.
Finish weld using stitch welding to prevent warpage.
Grind welds smooth and apply seam sealer to all joints.
Treat interior surfaces with rust preventive (POR-15 or equivalent).
Apply rubberized underseal to exterior underbody surfaces.
Prime and paint repaired areas to match existing finish.
Apply cavity wax to all hollow sections for ongoing protection.
tips: The 993 is a unibody - structural rust must be properly repaired for safety.
Battery acid damage is common - inspect even if battery has been relocated.
Spring plate covers often rust through - inspect carefully from below.
The 993 is now highly collectible - quality repairs preserve value.
Quality reproduction panels are available from Restoration Design and others.
POR-15 requires proper surface preparation - follow instructions exactly.
Consider professional inspection before purchasing a 993 to assess rust severity.
Cars from coastal or salt-road areas require extra diligence.
warnings: Extensive rust repair can affect the vehicle's collectible value - consult specialists.
Welding near fuel lines and tank requires proper safety precautions.
Improper structural repairs can affect crash safety - consult professionals if unsure.
MIG welding thin body panels requires skill to avoid burn-through.
Rust preventive coatings require proper ventilation and safety equipment.
Disconnect battery and fuel system before any welding operations.
The 993's value makes proper documentation of repairs important for resale.

guides.title: Electrical System Restoration
guides.description: Complete guide to diagnosing and restoring the 993's electrical system. Covers the DME relay, motronic system, ground connections, gauge cluster repair, and wiring harness inspection critical to reliable operation of the last air-cooled 911.
guides.interval: Inspect every 2-3 years, service as needed
tools: Small picks and probes for connectors
Torx and Phillips screwdrivers for interior panels
Porsche diagnostic tool (PST2 or equivalent) for ABS
steps: Disconnect battery before any electrical work - negative terminal first.
Test battery condition - load test and check voltage (should be 12.6V resting).
Clean and tighten all battery connections with terminal cleaner.
Test alternator output - should be 13.8-14.4V at idle.
Locate the relay panel in the front trunk area (fuse/relay carrier).
Identify DME relay position - pull and inspect for melted contacts.
Test DME relay with multimeter - replace if any doubt (common failure).
Inspect fuel pump relay - listen for click when key turns on.
Check and clean all ground connections - critical for proper operation.
Main engine ground is at transmission - clean and retorque.
Secondary grounds on body should be cleaned to bare metal.
Inspect wiring harness for rodent damage (common on stored cars).
The 993 uses Motronic 5.2 - check for stored codes with diagnostic tool.
Inspect spark plug wires for cracks, carbon tracking, or heat damage.
For gauge cluster issues, remove cluster (Torx screws from behind wheel).
Inspect and resolder cold solder joints on cluster circuit board.
Replace failed capacitors in cluster (common cause of gauge failure).
Test ABS system - warning lights indicate module or sensor issues.
ABS sensors can be cleaned and tested - wheel speed issues are common.
Test all lighting circuits - replace failed bulbs.
Inspect and clean multi-pin connectors throughout the vehicle.
Apply dielectric grease to all cleaned connections.
Reconnect battery and test all systems before closing up.
tips: The 993's DME relay is the most common cause of no-start conditions.
Keep a spare DME relay in the car - they can fail without warning.
Ground connections are critical - clean and protect with dielectric grease.
The gauge cluster capacitor kit is an inexpensive preventive repair.
Biodegradable wiring insulation attracts rodents - inspect stored cars carefully.
The 993 has more sophisticated electronics than the 964 - diagnostic tools help.
ABS module rebuilding is available and much cheaper than replacement.
Document any wiring changes with photographs for future reference.
warnings: Always disconnect battery before working on electrical systems.
The 993 has airbags - wait 10 minutes after disconnecting battery before working near steering wheel.
Incorrect relay replacement can damage the DME computer.
Brittle wiring can crack when handled - be gentle with original harnesses.
Static electricity can damage electronic components - ground yourself.
ABS hydraulic modulator contains high-pressure fluid - do not disassemble.
The Motronic system requires proper diagnostic equipment for codes.

guides.title: Interior Restoration
guides.description: Comprehensive interior restoration guide for the 993. Covers leather seat repair, carpet replacement, door panel restoration, dashboard care, and HVAC system service to return the cabin of this collectible 911 to pristine condition.
tools: Trim panel removal tools (plastic pry bars)
Hog ring pliers and hog rings
steps: Remove seats by unbolting from floor (4 bolts per seat, 13mm).
Disconnect any electrical connectors for power seats, heated seats, or sensors.
Inspect seat leather condition - clean with quality leather cleaner first.
For worn leather: apply Leatherique or similar conditioner system.
For cracked/torn leather: professional reupholstery or cover kit replacement.
Remove hog rings to separate leather from foam for cover replacement.
Replace foam cushions if compressed or degraded - common on driver's side.
Install new covers using hog rings at attachment points.
Remove door panels by removing screws behind handle pulls and popping clips.
Inspect door card backing - replace water barrier if damaged.
Clean or replace door panel fabric/leather as needed.
Remove old carpet by removing sill plates and seat bases.
Clean and treat floor pan with rust preventive if any bare metal.
Install new carpet kit, starting from rear and working forward.
Secure carpet with adhesive at edges and plastic retainers.
Clean dashboard with appropriate cleaner - avoid silicone products.
The 993 dashboard rarely cracks but clean and protect regularly.
Treat leather steering wheel with conditioner.
Replace shift and e-brake boots if cracked or worn.
Service HVAC system - test blend door operation for clicking or malfunction.
Replace blend door actuators if clicking or not responding.
Replace blower motor if noisy or weak airflow.
Test all interior functions before final assembly.
tips: The 993 interior is exceptionally well-made - often cleaning/conditioning is sufficient.
Leatherique's two-step system can revive severely dried leather.
Original colors can be matched with leather dye if minor touch-up needed.
The 993's supple leather responds well to conditioning.
Door panel clips are fragile - have extras on hand before removal.
The 993's HVAC blend door actuators commonly click or fail.
Steam cleaning is effective for carpet and fabric without chemicals.
Original floor mats are collectible - preserve if possible.
Interior condition significantly affects the 993's collectible value.
warnings: Airbag-equipped cars require care when removing steering wheel components.
Power seat wiring carries significant current - disconnect battery first.
Leather dyes can stain surrounding surfaces - mask carefully.
Silicone-based products leave residue that interferes with future repairs.
Heat gun can damage leather if held too close - keep moving.
The 993 is now a collector car - preserve originality where possible.
Some adhesives require ventilation - work in well-ventilated area.

used.notes: Search salvage yards - 993s are getting rare but parts still surface

tools.notes: Extensive library of 993 DIY articles with detailed step-by-step instructions

tools.notes: Complete torque specification reference for all 993 work

tools.name: Porsche 993 Technical Reference
tools.notes: Rennlist's 993 forum has decades of technical discussions and DIY guides

engine.notes: Hold one end while torquing the other

diyGuides.title: Oil Change
diyGuides.description: Complete oil and filter change for the M64 air-cooled flat-six.
tools: Ramps or jack and jack stands
steps: Warm the engine for 2-3 minutes - warm oil flows better.
Drive onto ramps or raise and support the car safely.
Locate the main drain plug on the bottom of the engine case.
Position large drain pan and remove the 21mm drain plug.
Allow oil to drain completely - 15-20 minutes for thorough drainage.
The spin-on oil filter is in the engine compartment, left side of engine.
Using filter wrench, remove the old filter.
Apply fresh oil to the new filter's gasket.
Thread new filter on by hand until seated, then 3/4 turn more.
Replace the copper crush washer on the drain plug.
Reinstall drain plug and torque to 37 ft-lbs (50 Nm).
Add 10-11 quarts of 15W-50 or 20W-50 oil through the filler.
Start engine and check for leaks at drain and filter.
Let idle briefly, shut off, wait 3 minutes, check level.
tips: Air-cooled engines need 10-11 quarts - the oil helps with cooling.
Use quality 15W-50 or 20W-50 oil - Mobil 1 15W-50 is popular.
Check for oil leaks at valve covers and chain tensioner while working.
The 993 has hydraulic lifters - no valve adjustment needed.

diyGuides.title: Brake Pad Replacement
diyGuides.description: Front and rear brake pad replacement on the 993's four-piston calipers.
steps: Loosen lug bolts while the car is on the ground.
Raise and support the car safely on jack stands.
Remove wheel to access the caliper.
The 993 uses four-piston fixed calipers - pads slide out without caliper removal.
Remove the pad retaining pins (cross pins through the caliper).
Use a flathead screwdriver to push and slide the old pads out.
Inspect rotor for scoring, cracks, or minimum thickness markings.
Clean the caliper pad contact surfaces with brake cleaner.
Use the piston spreader tool to push all four pistons back evenly.
Apply brake grease to the back of new pads.
Slide new pads into the caliper, ensuring proper orientation.
Reinstall pad retaining pins.
Reinstall wheel and torque lug bolts to 96 ft-lbs (130 Nm).
Repeat for all corners.
Pump brake pedal until firm before driving.
tips: Four-piston calipers require all pistons pushed back evenly.
Open brake fluid reservoir before compressing pistons.
Use quality pads from Pagid, Hawk, or Porsche OEM.
Bed new pads with gradual stops - avoid hard braking for 100 miles.

diyGuides.title: Spark Plug Replacement
diyGuides.description: Replace spark plugs on the M64 flat-six engine.
steps: Allow engine to cool completely before starting.
Open engine lid for access to the top of the engine.
The 993 has 6 spark plugs - one per cylinder, accessible from above.
Remove the spark plug wire by pulling on the boot, not the wire.
Mark or note wire positions if concerned about mixing them up.
Use compressed air to blow debris away from the spark plug wells.
Using spark plug socket and extension, remove each plug.
Inspect old plugs - note condition (gap wear, color, fouling).
Apply a thin coat of anti-seize to new plug threads.
Hand-thread new plugs into the head to avoid cross-threading.
Torque spark plugs to 18-22 ft-lbs (25-30 Nm).
Reconnect spark plug wires firmly onto the new plugs.
Start engine and verify smooth operation.
tips: The firing order is 1-6-2-4-3-5 - cylinder 1 is front right.
Use Bosch or NGK plugs specified for the 993.
Inspect plug wires for cracks or carbon tracking while replacing plugs.
A universal joint helps access plugs in tight areas.

diyGuides.title: Serpentine Belt Replacement
diyGuides.description: Replace accessory drive belt and inspect tensioner.
tools: Belt routing diagram (in engine bay or manual)
steps: Open engine lid and locate the serpentine belt on the front of the engine.
Note or photograph the belt routing before removal.
Locate the automatic belt tensioner - usually has a 15mm bolt head.
Using the 15mm wrench, rotate the tensioner to release belt tension.
Slip the old belt off the pulleys while holding tensioner back.
Slowly release the tensioner.
Inspect the old belt for cracks, glazing, or missing ribs.
Inspect the tensioner pulley - spin it by hand, feel for roughness or play.
Route the new belt according to the diagram, leaving tensioner pulley for last.
Rotate the tensioner again and slip the belt over the tensioner pulley.
Release the tensioner slowly - it will take up the belt slack.
Verify the belt is properly seated in all pulley grooves.
Start the engine and observe belt tracking for a few seconds.
tips: Take a photo of belt routing before removal for reference.
If the tensioner pulley is worn or noisy, replace it with the belt.
A cracked or glazed belt can slip and cause accessory issues.
Check all pulleys for smooth rotation while the belt is off.

engine.name: Perform valve adjustment
engine.description: Last air-cooled 911 - hydraulic lifters on some variants

engine.name: Replace chain tensioners with updated parts
Inspect/replace heat exchangers
engine.description: Critical for cabin heat and emissions

engine.name: Reseal engine case and covers
engine.description: Oil leaks at case halves, cam covers

fuel.name: Replace rubber fuel lines
fuel.description: Critical safety item - check for deterioration

buyersGuide.overview: The Porsche 993 (1995-1998) is the last of the air-cooled 911s and represents the pinnacle of the classic 911 design. With its completely redesigned multilink rear suspension, the 993 finally tamed the 911's notorious handling quirks while maintaining the visceral air-cooled experience. The Varioram-equipped 3.6L engine produces 272-282 hp in naturally aspirated form, while the twin-turbo models make 400-450 hp. The 993 has become the most collectible modern 911, with prices far exceeding those of newer water-cooled models.

variants.name: Carrera / Carrera S
variants.description: Rear-wheel drive with 272-282 hp. The S adds widebody styling and larger wheels. Pure driving experience.

variants.name: Carrera 4 / Carrera 4S
variants.description: All-wheel drive variants. More stable but heavier. The 4S combines AWD with widebody.

variants.name: Targa
variants.description: Glass-roof variant with sliding glass panel. Unique styling but complex mechanism.

variants.name: Turbo / Turbo S
variants.description: Twin-turbocharged with 400-450 hp. The last air-cooled Turbo. Turbo S is extremely rare and valuable.

variants.name: GT2
variants.description: Rear-wheel drive Turbo with 430+ hp. Widebody, no driver aids. The ultimate air-cooled 911.

variants.name: Cabriolet
variants.description: Full convertible variant. Adds weight and reduces rigidity but popular.

items.detail: Check chain housings, cam covers, and case halves. Air-cooled engines weep oil but should not drip heavily.
Critical test for air-cooled engines. Should show healthy, even compression across cylinders.
Listen for chain rattle on cold start. Tensioners should be updated to latest design.
1996+ cars have Varioram. Check for proper operation - engine should have strong mid-range pull.
Check for shaft play, boost leaks, and proper boost control. Twin K24 turbos are expensive.
Test all gears including reverse. Check for popping out of gear. Synchros can wear.
Check for smooth shifting and proper kickdown. Valve body issues can develop.
Should engage smoothly mid-pedal. Dual-mass flywheel is expensive to replace.
Test for proper engagement in turns. LSD is desirable option.
The 993's sophisticated rear suspension has many bushings and joints that wear.
Check for leaking struts and worn bushings causing clunks.
Check rockers, floor pans, and battery area. Less common but still possible.
If Targa, check glass roof operation and seals for leaks.
Biodegradable wire sheathing attracts rodents. Check for damage throughout car.
Common failure point causing no-start. Easy and cheap fix.
HVAC system is complex. Test all functions.

project.description: Cars needing engine work or with significant issues. Still valuable due to air-cooled status.

driver.description: Running and driving Carrera or Carrera 4 with some needs.

concours.description: Turbo, Turbo S, GT2, or exceptional low-mileage examples. Prices are strong.

redFlags: Turbo models with boost control issues
whatToLookFor: Recent compression/leak-down test with good results
Widebody (S or 4S) for best looks and value
expertTips: The 993 is the most collectible modern 911 - prices reflect this
Carrera S and 4S widebody cars command significant premiums
Varioram engines (1997-98) have better mid-range power
Manual transmissions are strongly preferred over Tiptronic
Turbo and GT2 prices have reached supercar levels
Budget for proper pre-purchase inspection by a specialist
Join Rennlist.com for excellent technical resources
Parts availability is good but prices are high
A well-maintained 993 is an appreciating asset
These are the last air-cooled 911s - that matters to collectors

youtube.name: PCA YouTube
youtube.description: Porsche Club buyer guides and tech tips
